journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part M: Journal of Engineering for the Maritime Environment

title-group.article-title: Simple hydroelastic impact models for water-borne debris

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Hawaii at Manoa, Honolulu, HI, USA
2Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of Hawaii at Manoa, Honolulu, HI, USA

author-notes.corresp: Marecelo H. Kobayashi, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Hawaii at Manoa, 2540 Dole St, Holmes Hall 302, Honolulu, HI 96822, USA. Email: marcelok@hawaii.edu

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on Hydroelasticity Theories and Applications

abstract.p: Debris driven by tsunamis pose a significant threat to structures, and yet most building codes that include debris impact are based on rigid-body dynamics. However, the debris will most likely not be rigid compared to the structural components, such as walls and columns, that they impact. Impact by flexible, water-borne wood poles and shipping containers is considered in this paper. A relatively simple one-dimensional model for acoustic wave propagation, for which an analytical solution is obtained, is shown to provide a good estimate for the initial impact force and duration. This model is validated with small-scale, in-air tests. The simple model is also validated with two-dimensional fluid–structure interaction using a finite element code. The acoustic model works well for initial impact as long as the debris rebounds from the impact target. When the water prevents separation, then the acoustic model significantly overestimates the asymptotic force. The effect of the gravitational waves resulting from impact is to retard re-impacts, as compared to the acoustic model.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: It is well recognized that debris driven by tsunamis pose a significant threat to structures in the inundation zone,1 and for life-safety it is especially important to consider such debris when designing vertical tsunami evacuation shelters.2 Structures such as fuel tanks, and port and industrial facilities are also at risk from debris impact. Hurricane-driven debris pose similar threats. Shipping containers are ubiquitous, especially in port locations. Standard 6.10 m and 12.2 m (20 ft and 40 ft) containers have empty weights of 2230 and 3700 kg, respectively, and full weights of 24,000 and 30,500 kg. The two sizes, when full, would have nominal drafts of approximately 1.58 m and 0.914 m, respectively. Hence, floating containers can pose a significant impact threat to structures in the path of the flow.

To properly design structures to resist these demands it is necessary to be able to quantify the impact forces generated by these events. Impact of high-mass debris driven by water at relatively low velocities has received some attention, especially with respect to flood-borne woody debris,3–5 barge collision on bridge piers and navigation locks,6,7 and a few authors have also considered shipping containers.8,9 Guidelines for debris impact forces, at least in the United States, are based on rigid-body impact dynamics, as well as experimental data. Nevertheless, there is no consensus on how to define these forces. ASCE 7,10 the Coastal Construction Manual (CCM),11 and FEMA P6462 focus on building structures, while AASHTO12 focuses on vessel collision with bridge piers and a US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) document13 focuses on barge impact on navigation locks.
ASCE 7’s approach, based on impulse momentum and two rigid bodies, is fairly common and results in an equation of the form

in which F is the impact force, mp is the total mass of the projectile, vf is the impact velocity, and Δt is the time to reduce the debris velocity to zero. The value for Δt recommended by ASCE 7 is 0.03 s, while CCM, with a similar equation, recommends values from 0.1 to 1.0 s. The result of these different recommendations is an order of magnitude difference in impact force.14 As a consequence, the structural designer is unclear what time to use.2 In addition, some guidelines include a provision to increase the force to account for the water inertia; see for example FEMA2 and AASHTO.12 Paczkowski et al.15 discuss the different formulations in more detail.

According to Goldsmith,16 application of rigid-body impact theory is appropriate if the duration of impact, i.e. time of contact, is much larger than the natural period of each of the impacting bodies. Because this may not be the case with the debris, Paczkowski et al.15 investigated the impact forces when the debris is flexible. The authors focused on validating the application of the one-dimensional (1D) acoustic wave equation to debris impact in-air. Their work is extended herein to consider in more detail the effects of the fluid on the impact forces as well as considering the effect of the gravity wave resulting from impact, which has a larger timescale than the acoustic waves. The impact model proposed herein involves an elastic, possibly nonuniform, projectile hitting a rigid wall, with or without the inclusion of a contact stiffness. The impact forces are determined based on the acoustic-wave propagation in the projectile in the short timescale, followed by the gravity-wave forces induced by the impact in the longer timescale.

The paper is organized as follows. In the next section, the analytical model is presented. Results are discussed in the subsequent section, including comparison of the analytical model with numerical simulations. The final section contains conclusions from the present study and suggestions for future work.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The proposed analytical, 1D model of the debris impact comprises a solid body and a fluid phase. The solid phase is modeled by two segments of (possibly) dissimilar materials. The initial state is the projectile and fluid moving with uniform speed v0 before the projectile hits a rigid wall; see Figure 1. Note that the water is essentially constrained to move in a tube; i.e. there is no free surface. Hence, this model will be quite conservative in the sense that it will overpredict the effect of the fluid on the impact forces, at least in the acoustic timescale.

sec.title: Fluid phase
sec.p: The acoustic equations in the fluid phase can be written as

where aL=KL/ρL is the sound speed in the fluid, KL is the fluid bulk modulus, ρL is the fluid density, vL is the acoustic velocity, and pL is the acoustic pressure. Equations (1) and (2) constitute a linear, hyperbolic system with constant coefficients
where wL=[pLvL]† and
The eigenvalues of AL are λ±=±aL so that
where Λ=diag(λ−,λ+) and
Premultiplying equation (3) by S−1 and defining the Riemann invariants, iL=[lLrL]†, iL=S−1wL we obtain
and

Thus rL (resp. lL) travels to the right (resp. left) at constant speed aL. Because we assume the fluid to extend to infinity, there is no reflection from infinity arriving at finite time at the fluid–solid interface so that lL(L2,t)=−ρLaLv0|L2, or
at all times.

sec.title: Solid phase
sec.p: In the solid, the longitudinal displacement, u, is assumed small, yielding the classical wave equation

where ai=(Ei/ρi) is the sound speed, Ei are the Young’s moduli, ρi the density, and the subscripts i=1,2 represent the segments of dissimilar materials. For future reference, Ai are the cross-sectional areas of the segments. For well-posedness, we specify initial conditions
a boundary condition
and compatibility conditions between the dissimilar materials
and between the projectile and fluid
Combining equations (4) and (9) makes it possible to account for the water effects on the solid through the boundary condition
Similarly to the fluid phase, we can define left and right Riemann invariants as
where vi=∂ui∂t is the velocity and εi=∂ui∂x the strain. These invariants move at constant speed to the left, li, and right, ri, respectively, that is
Any initial boundary conditions or compatibility conditions written for ui can be readily transformed to the Riemann invariants using the matrix relation
where
Thus, given general initial conditions
where ui,0 and vi,0 are given functions of the coordinate x∈Ii in some interval Ii⊂ℝ and for each body i=1,2, we obtain
In particular, the initial conditions (6) become
For boundary conditions, we consider a general linear form
where αi, βi and ϕi are fixed functions of t>0, and xb,1=−L1 and xb,2=L2. Then, the corresponding boundary conditions for the Riemann invariants are
where
The boundary conditions (7) and (10) are particular instances of equation (13)
Finally, with respect to the Riemann invariants, the compatibility conditions (8) can be written as

The physical interpretation of the wave transformation is that the left and right invariants carry their energy from an originating noncharacteristic curve into the domain. For instance, the noncharacteristic curve for the left invariant at the first segment comprises the length of the segment and the time line at the interface between the first and second segments. Let Ti=2Li/ai denote the phase time in each domain;17 that is, twice the time for the sound wave to traverse the segment. Thus for t<T1/2, the left invariant at the wall domain will carry, unaltered, its initial conditions at t=0 and x∈[−L1,0] into the domain until it meets the left boundary at xb,1=−L1. At the latter, part of the energy brought to this boundary by the left invariant is reflected, according to the boundary condition (14) applied to xb,1=−L1, and carried back into the domain by the right invariant originating from that boundary. The right invariant will then carry that exchanged energy within the first segment until the interface between the first and second segments. There, the converging Riemann invariants to the interface, namely, the right invariant in the first segment and the left invariant in the second segment, will exchange their energy with the outgoing characteristics at the same interface, namely, the left invariant in the first segment and the right invariant in the second segment. The left invariant originating at the interface will then bring the exchanged content back into the first segment and this process will repeat indefinitely – thus defining the wave transformation for all points in the domain and at all times.

In this context, an analytical solution can be obtained using the characteristics method for the wave transformation described above, where the characteristic curves for the left invariant (resp. right invariant) is ξl,i=x+ait (resp. ξr,i=x−ait).

sec.title: Parameter reduction
sec.p: The equations above show that the stress at the interface between the projectile and the wall, σ0, can be written as

The dependence expressed in this equation already involves a reduction of parameters. For example, the derivation above shows that the stress σ0 depends on the product ρLaL rather than on their individual values. Using the Buckingham Π theorem allows us to further reduce the number of parameters by three
where τa=(T1+T2)/2.

sec.title: Water impact
sec.p: The water wave transformation involves two distinct timescales. The first is the acoustic and is given by the phase τa. The second relates to the water wave build-up behind the projectile and is given by τg=h/g, where h is the water height at impact. Under normal circumstances, τa≪τg, and the water effects can be split in two parts. During the acoustic phase, the water height is assumed constant and equal to the impact height. This initial height affects the interaction area between the fluid and the projectile and can be accommodated by modifying equation (9b) as

where A2 and AL are the effective projectile and fluid areas, respectively. Note that as can be seen in the simulations below, the acoustics with the free surface differ in significant aspects from the 1D assumption above. The interest in the results from the 1D model lies in the conservative upper bound for the water effect on the impact that it provides.

The second part, where the water wave builds up behind the projectile, involves highly nonlinear phenomena such as splashing and violent pressure peaks18 and is studied using a finite element analysis (FEA) tool in this work.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In the following, unless otherwise noted, the forces are nondimensionalized by the analytical impact force ρ1a1A1v0 (see Paczkowski et al.15), and for a uniform projectile time is nondimensionalized by (L1+L2)/a1.

sec.title: Steel tube
sec.p: Small-scale experiments were conducted to compare the acoustic, in-air impact model with real impact data. The experimental setup represented direct impact by a projectile. The projectiles consisted of a standard rectangular steel tube 5.08 cm × 5.08 cm × 0.3175 cm, see Figure 2. The projectile traveled along a guide system fabricated from steel angle sections. The projectiles impacted a steel plate attached to a 244 kN (55 kip) load cell (model MTS 661.23A01), which itself was attached to a stiffened angle bracket (Figure 2). The projectiles were accelerated manually down the guide track. Impact velocity was determined through the use of highspeed video and the time it took for the projectile to travel from 3 cm to 1 cm in front of the load cell. The experiments are described in more detail in Paczkowski et al.15

To obtain analytical results to compare with the experimental data, the following properties were used: Ep=210 GPa, Ap=5.42 cm2, and ρp=7850 kg/mkg/m3. Figure 3 shows the comparison of nondimensional force, F¯=F/(ρpApapv0), versus nondimensional time, t¯=t/(Lp/ap), for six trials with a projectile of length Lp=2 m. The experimental data, which are the force time-histories recorded from the load cell, are identified by the impact velocity in m/s. For a rigid wall, the analytical results show a jump in force from zero to one at impact. The force remains constant for a nondimensional time of two (the time for the acoustic wave to travel down the projectile and back again), at which point it drops instantaneously to zero. However, as is typical,19 the recorded data saw a more gradual increase and decrease. This type of behavior can be obtained by the addition of a contact stiffness, kc.15 The inclusion of kc requires changing the boundary condition at the wall from rigid, v|−L1=0, to Newton’s third law for a spring: kcu|−L1=ALE1ε|−L1. The displacement u(t)|−L1 at x=−L1 is obtained by trapezoid quadrature of the velocity: u(t)|−L1=∫0tv(s)|−L1ds. Results for k¯=kcLp/EpAp=4,6 and 8 are shown in Figure 3. The results for k¯=6 probably best match the initial slope and duration of impact. The results for the other two values are shown to illustrate the sensitivity of the results to the value of k¯. It should be noted that the stiffness of the load cell, based on the manufacturer’s specification, is much higher than these values, so it is unlikely that the load cell stiffness is the reason for this behavior. The high-frequency oscillations in the plateau region of the force time history is also typical of these kinds of experiments.19 However, the increase in force during this region is likely due to wave propagation in the load cell. As can be seen, this simple model gives a good estimate for both the impact force and impact duration. Comparison with additional experimental data can be found in Paczkowski et al.15

caption.p: Comparison of experimental and analytical nondimensional impact forces.

sec.title: Floating wood poles
sec.p: The impact of a wood utility pole on a rigid wall was also considered. The pole is 12.2 m long with Ep=11.2 GPa. Two specific gravities were considered: 0.5 and 0.25 (based on seawater). The heavier pole corresponds to a wood slightly denser than would normally be used for a utility pole, while the lighter pole corresponds to a lighter wood than would be used. The two values of specific gravity correspond to A¯=AL/A2=0.5 and 0.25, respectively. These two examples bound the density of real poles. Water properties were ρL=1025 kg/m3 and aL=1560 m/s.

The impact force time-history for the heavier pole is shown in Figure 4. The pole hits the wall at time 0, and then rebounds away from the wall at time 2. The water pushes it against the wall again at time 4, at a lower velocity and hence lower impact force. The pole does not separate again from the wall. The horizontal line corresponds to the impact force of the water on the wetted end of the pole, and is given by the product ρ¯a¯A¯v0, where ρ¯=ρL/ρ2 and a¯=aL/a2. The force converges to that value as the average velocity of the pole drops to zero.

The impact force time-history for the lighter pole is shown in Figure 5. The response is similar, except that the pole separates for a longer time (less area is exposed to the water). It also has two impacts.

sec.title: Floating shipping containers
sec.p: The head-on (longitudinal) impact of a standard 40 ft (12.2 m) shipping container is investigated for both the full and empty conditions. Again, Ep=210 GPa and ρp=7850 kg/m3. In the longitudinal direction, the structural stiffness of the container comes from the two top and the two bottom beams. Therefore, the approximate area of these beams was used in the model. Because the mass density of steel was used, the mass of the projectile was much less than the total mass, which includes the nonstructural mass. The structural mass used in the analysis was 741 kg, whereas an empty container weighs 3700 kg. However, the draft of the containers was calculated based on the total mass. For the empty and full shipping containers, A¯=40 and 300, respectively, were used. (To understand the effect of nonstructural mass on the impact force will require either experiments or a more sophisticated model.)

Figure 6 shows the impact force for both empty and full containers. In both cases, there is no separation. Both time-histories converge asymptotically to the impact force from the water alone (for the full container, that value is 11.8). The empty container converges quickly to this value, whereas the full container requires many cycles. It appears that the effect of the fluid (the added mass effect) may be to increase the dry impact force several times.

caption.p: Impact force for empty and full containers.

sec.title: Double projectiles
sec.p: The case of a wood pole followed by a shipping container is now considered. The wood pole hits the wall, and the shipping container is essentially connected to the pole at the opposite end. The material properties for the two projectiles are the same as above. The ratio of the pole area to the structural area of the container is 9.425. There is no fluid in this case. The wall impact force and the force between the pole and the container are shown in Figure 7, where t¯=2t/T1. In this case, the container delays the wood pole from rebounding from the wall until slightly less than time 4, while the pole and container separate at slightly less than time 5. The forces are nondimensionalized by the nominal impact force in the pole. The ratio of the nominal impact force in the pole to the force in the container is 0.527. Hence, if the force had been nondimensionalized by the nominal force in the container, the maximum force would be 0.84, i.e. less than direct impact from the container – the wood pole acts as a buffer and reduces the impact from the container.

caption.p: Wood pole followed by a shipping container.

sec.title: FEA simulations
sec.p: Impact by a wood pole and by a container, both driven by a fluid, was simulated using the finite element program LS-DYNA version 971.R5.1.1. Two-dimensional (2D) simulations were carried out to quantify the effect of the free surface and the gravity waves following the acoustic phase. The wood pole was simulated with elastic elements (model 1: ELASTIC) with one element in the thickness dimension; all degrees of freedom in the out-of-plane dimension were restrained for two-dimensionality. The fluid was modeled with eight-node fluid elements (model 9: NULL with Gruneisen equation of state (EOS)). A sample mesh is shown in Figure 8. There was no water below the pole; rather it rested on rollers so that it was free to move horizontally. The pole hit a rigid wall; both the pole and the fluid had an initial velocity of 6 m/s.

caption.p: Example of mesh used in the computation of the wood pole impact dynamics.

sec.p: The water was modeled as a compressible fluid governed by Euler’s equations with first-order advection, and a Gruneisen EOS is used with the following parameters: ρL=1025 kg/m3, aL=1489m/s, s=1.79 and γ0=1.65. Three quadrature points are used for the coupling. The heavy pole case was considered, with a specific gravity of 0.5 relative to seawater ρp=512.5 kg/m3 and a Young’s modulus of Ep=11.2 GPa. Three meshes were considered: mesh 1, 2 and 3 comprising 25,840, 103,360 and 137,600 finite elements, respectively. The normalized force at the wall is shown in Figure 9. The FEA results for the acoustics agree quite well with the 1D analytical model from above. LS-DYNA uses an internal contact stiffness to control the impact dynamics, and this contact stiffness apparently led to the finite rise time in the impact force shown in the figure. In this case, it appears that the 1D model approximates the initial impact well.

caption.p: Impact force by a wood pole: comparison of 2D finite element results and 1D analytical results.

sec.p: After the rebound, because the water is not confined, as is assumed in the simple 1D acoustic model, the water behind the pole initially rises in a vertical jet behind the pole. A simple physically motivated, reduced-order model to estimate the force on the projectile for this phenomenon is a rigid-body projectile interacting with the incoming horizontal jet, which is deflected upward into a vertical jet. The force due to the horizontal jet is significantly smaller than the corresponding force predicted using the 1D acoustic model above. Indeed, after the rebound, the kinetic energy in the horizontal jet is mainly transformed into gravitational potential energy, thus reducing the water force on the pole. Based on this reduced-order model, an analytical solution for the motion of a rigid projectile can be found as
and

where vp is the projectile speed, up is the projectile displacement, v0=6 m/s is the incoming water speed, K=C/Lp, Lp=12.2 m is projectile length, C is a correction factor for draft, t0=1/(K(vp0+v0)), with vp0=5.8 m/s the initial velocity of the projectile when it hits the wall. The comparisons of the predicted projectile speed and displacement using equations (16) and (17), and the corresponding computed projectile speed and displacement using LS-DYNA are shown in Figure 10. To obtain the curves for equations (16) and (17), the value of C=0.775 was chosen to match the peak FEA displacement.

caption.p: Comparison between analytical and computational results for the velocity (a) and displacement (b) of the projectile. The red solid circles between 1 and 1.5 s mark the instant when the projectile reverses its motion.

sec.p: Figure 10 shows good agreement between the reduced-order model and computational results up to the point where the projectile reverses its motion. After this point, there is a period of relaxation lasting about 0.2 s followed by a period where the velocity changes linearly until the second impact. To understand these phases of the flow, Figure 11 shows the topology of the flow between the first and second impacts. The two phases of jet and constant force depicted in Figure 10 can be recognized in Figure 11, where the jet extends up to about 1.2 s and the constant force starts around 1.6 s. The water jet is discernible at t=0.4,0.8,1.2s, while a nearly constant column of water behind the projectile can be noticed at t=2–3.2 s. This constant column of water would provide a constant (hydrostatic) force and a consequent constant acceleration and velocity slope.

caption.p: Fluid flow topology between the first and second impacts.

sec.p: The second impact occurs around 3.2 s, and because the velocity of the second impact is smaller than the first impact, the water does not increase the impact force.

The 12.2 m shipping container was also modeled with LS-DYNA, again to understand the two-dimensionality of the response. The model is shown in Figure 12. The shipping container was modeled by elastic elements to represent the top and bottom beams, as shown. The 1.61 mm thickness of the elements was determined to match the mass of the beams, similar to the area of the beams used above. The thickness is small because the actual structural area is smeared over the width of the container (2.44 m) to obtain a 2D model. As for the pole, the container is on rollers. Because the beams are so thin, they have very little bending stiffness. Therefore, rollers were put along the top of the top beam as well. Massless (ρ = 1 kg/m3) rigid plates were put at the front and back of the container to represent the container ends and to tie the top and bottom beams together. The draft of the full container was considered. The same fluid model as used for the pole was used here. In this case, there were four meshes: mesh 1, 2, 3 and 4 with 9175, 36,700, 146,800 and 278,800 finite elements, respectively. Note that the purpose of this FE analysis is to assess 2D effects not accounted for in the 1D model. Full three-dimensional (3D) effects would be best handled with more complex 3D FE structural as well as fluid models, and experiments.

caption.p: Example of mesh used in the computation of the shipping container impact dynamics.

sec.p: The normalized impact forces in the bottom beam and the top beam are shown in Figure 13. These forces in the top and bottom beam are normalized independently; hence the initial impact force is approximately 1 for both (as compared to 0.5). This figure should be compared with the full container in Figure 6. As can be seen, the impact force follows the 1D model prediction quite well until the wave has propagated down the container and returned to the wall (t¯=2). At that point, the top beam, which was not exposed to water, rebounds from the wall while the force in the bottom beam increases. But the top beam apparently starts to pull it away, and the force drops quickly. The effect of the water is significantly different than what the 1D model predicts (Figure 6).

caption.p: Impact force by a container: comparison of 2D finite element results and 1D analytical results. (a) Top beam; (b) bottom beam

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A simple 1D model to obtain the force on a rigid wall during flexible debris impact during the acoustic response phase has been presented. The model allows the analytical solution to be obtained for a nonuniform projectile propelled by water (or air). The addition of a Hertzian-type contact stiffness allows the impact force to rise gradually, as compared to the sudden jump that happens with rigid impact between the wall and projectile front. The solution agrees well with small-scale experiments in-air, and confirms that the impact force is not a function of the total mass, as is often assumed in the code equations. When water drives the projectile, multiple impacts will occur under certain circumstances, and the model easily deals with the separation and re-impact.

The analytical 1D results are compared with results from a 2D finite element analysis, which includes the free surface. The initial impact force and duration of impact, during the first phase of the acoustic wave propagation, is predicted well by the 1D model. However, after the acoustic wave from the water reaches the wall, the dynamics can be quite different if separation does not occur. While the 1D model is conservative, in some cases it can be too conservative. Based on the 2D models, the increase of the impact force by the presence of the water can be much less than the 1D model predicts.

The influence of the gravity waves on the impact force happens at a much longer timescale than the initial acoustic impact response. The effect of the gravitational phase is to retard the subsequent impact, but it does not increase the impact force.

In general, the fluid does not increase the impact force for solid projectiles, such as the pole. For skeletal structures, such as the container, the fluid may increase the maximum impact force, because of the large fluid-to-structure area ratio, but additional work is needed to quantify and clarify this.

Future work should include the three-dimensionality of the wave propagation in the fluid, and the fluid in front of the projectile. Both of these effects are expected to decrease the force demand on the structure. In addition, the effect of non-structural mass on the impact forces, as well as the important effects of the wall flexibility, need to be considered. All of these effects are most likely best modeled with 3D FEA and through experiments.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: a sound speed
A area
E Young’s modulus
k stiffness
l left Riemann invariant
L length
p pressure
r right Riemann invariant
t time
T phase
u displacement
v velocity
x space coordinate
ε strain
ρ density
σ stress
τa average phase

sec.title: Subscripts
sec.p: 0 instant t = 0
1, 2 segment 1, 2
L fluid
